TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {103074=Last update: June 15, 2005, 1263=Researchers of family history of Europeans in India, for the period between 1713 and 1948. usually use the Ecclesiastical returns found in the British Library and LDS centers as the primary source of records for marriages, baptisms and burials.    In addition, it is often found that Thackers Directories are a valuable source of information.   Published each year and covering the period until Indian Independence in 1947 the Directories contain annual lists of civilian European and prominent Indian residents which help to place many individuals in specific places and points in time and allows careers in India to be traced.   Military Officers are listed in the East India Registers and Army Lists.    Unfortunately only officers are listed, not the many thousands who made up the other ranks.    Women are rarely mentioned unless they have standing in their own right as principals or teachers in schools; owners and managers of boarding houses, missionaries etc.   The most extensive and comprehensive collection of directories for India is held in the Oriental and India Office Collections (OIOC) at the British Library, however, collections of reference material can be found in many libraries around the world., 11932="Returns of baptisms, marriages and burials, relating mainly to European and Eurasian Christians in India, Burma and other areas administrated by the East India Company and the Government of India.    The returns were transmitted by chaplains and ministers to the Government of India, and thence to the India Office, primarily for record purposes.   Apart from the series for the three Indian presidencies (Bengal 1713-1948; Madras 1698-1948, and Bombay, 1709-1948), there are returns for St Helena (1767-1835), Fort Marlborough (1759-1825), Penang (1799-1829), Macao and Whampoa (1820-1833), Burma (1937-1957), India and Pakistan (1949-1968), Kuwait (1937-1961), and Aden (1840-1969).   Copies of the contemporary indexes and microfilm of many of the registers may be consulted directly in the Reading Room.", 6583=Thacker, Spink & Co was a well known Calcutta publishing company.   Their directories are well known and comprehensive.  In particular, Thackers Bengal Directory which was published 1864 - 1884 covered the presidency of Bengal; but from 1885 was expanded to cover the whole of India and its title was changed to Thackers Indian Directory.   It continued to be published until 1960., 102452=© 1997 - 2005 by Ian Poyntz All Rights Reserved Click on this mail box if you would like to send an e-mail to me (you will need to remove    "-nospam-"    from the address line)}
textBeforeTable: Thackers Directories Directories that are available on the open shelves of the   OIOC   back to:   Table of Contents   In the following tables the OIR shelfmarks are available on the open shelves of the Oriental and India Office Reading Room, the P.P. shelfmarks are contained in the Humanities collections but can be requested for consultation in the OIOC reading room, and the B.S. and I.S. shelfmarks are in the Official Publications and Social Sciences Collections, which are on 2nd floor directly below the OIOC reading room. Additional reference material of use to family historians is included in the Oriental and India Office Collections, the Humanities Collections and the Official Publications and Social Sciences Collections. "Returns of baptisms, marriages and burials, relating mainly to European and Eurasian Christians in India, Burma and other areas administrated by the East India Company and the Government of India.    The returns were transmitted by chaplains and ministers to the Government of India, and thence to the India Office, primarily for record purposes.   Apart from the series for the three Indian presidencies (Bengal 1713-1948; Madras 1698-1948, and Bombay, 1709-1948), there are returns for St Helena (1767-1835), Fort Marlborough (1759-1825), Penang (1799-1829), Macao and Whampoa (1820-1833), Burma (1937-1957), India and Pakistan (1949-1968), Kuwait (1937-1961), and Aden (1840-1969).   Copies of the contemporary indexes and microfilm of many of the registers may be consulted directly in the Reading Room." Visitors to the OIOC Reading Room
